lesson.description: HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language. It is the standard markup language for creating Web pages HTML describes the structure of a Web page and consists of a series of elements. HTML elements tell the browser how to display the content also its elements label pieces of content such as "this is a heading", "this is a paragraph", "this is a link", etc.

p: Allows us to write a paragraph within the tags, just like a description of a certain thing!

description

h: We can write our headers in here with the following order from the biggest to the smallest h1, h2, ... , h6.

header
a: This is a very useful tag that we can use to link to other web pages! we have to use the attribute href inorder to provide the link! link
Semantic Elements:

nav: Simply defines navigation links and helps us navigate between different pages. <nav> Navigation Links </nav>
header: funstions as a header for a document or section of the page. <header> Document Header </header>
footer: Basically acts as a footer for a document or section of the page. <footer> Document Footer </footer>
section: This is where the general information of the page is usually stored. <section> Document Secotion </section>
article: Article is where the more detailed information about the page is stored. <article> Document Article </article>

assignment.description: Create a website containing headers, paragraphs, and a link describing planet earth!

lesson.description: We use inputs simply to take information from the user in order to process it. There are different ways to collect information/input in html such as:
Input Type Text:
Takes the text from the user through the input form
Input Type Password:
Takes the password from the user through the input form and hides it
Input Type Submit:
A submit button which would be configured to trigger a submission of the form
Input Type Radio:
You can only choose one of the radio buttons
Input Type Checkbox:
You can choose zero or more of the boxes

lesson.description: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets and describes how HTML elements are to be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media. CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once External stylesheets are stored in CSS files
Text Color:
"color" attribute specifies the color of text
css text: color: blue;
Background Color:
"background-color" attribute specifies the background color of text
css text: background-color: grey;
Border Color:
"border-color" attribute specifies the border color of text, note that we must also include the border size
css text: border: 2px solid red;

assignment.description: Create a website with a blue paragraph, yellow background and a black border.

lesson.description: Text Font Family:
"font-family" attribute specifies the family of the font
css text: font-family: "Times New Roman", Times, serif;
Text Font Size:
"font-size" attribute specifies the size of the font
css text: font-family: "Times New Roman", Times, serif; font-size: 24px;
Text Alignment:
"text-align" attribute specifies the alignment of the text, default text is aligned to the left
css text: text-align: right;
css text: text-align: center;

lesson.description: Selectors:
If you take a look at the previous example it might confuse you as why css text for both cases of alignment is actually the same! We use "selectors" to distinguish between these elements!
For example, to apply an attribute to all the paragraphs we do the following: p {color: blue} Now all the paragraphs will be shown in blue text if we apply this
To distinguish between different elements of the same type we can use classes or ids

To assign a class "blue" to a certain paragraph we do the following:

Paragraph
Now in css only add a "." before the class name to apply a certain style only specific to any element with class "blue"
css text: .blue {color: blue}
It is almost the exact same way with ids, only the way to declare them is a bit different.
In css we just add "#" before the id name, and then simply write our css text in the same manner.
